example1.title: Initial Master Branch
example1.label: This is the starting point for the flow.  The Master branch should always be in synch with Production.

example1.title: Development Branch
example1.label: The Development branch is intially created off of the Master branch.  Feature branches intended for the next release should be merged into this branch when they are ready to be pushed to an integration test server for additional testing

example1.title: Product Hot Fixes
example1.label: To address hot fixes to deal with Production problems a bug branch is created off of master.

example1.title: Merge into Development
example1.label: The hot fix should be merged back into the development branch so that testing can proceed with as close a representation of the code as it will look when deployed to Production as possible.  This is ideally done by merging the master branch back into development.

example1.title: A Second Hotfix
example1.label: This is another hotfix, this one being worked in parallel with an addiitonal hotfix.  This one is targeted to be pushed to production first.

example1.title: Feature Branch
example1.label: Feature development can go on in parallel.  Each feature is worked on in its own branch.  When the feature is complete it can be merged into the development branch.  If there are questions about whether to include the feature in the release it should not be merged until those questions are resolved.
Multiple feature branches can be worked on in parallel.

When the development branch is ready for release a release branch is created off of development.  Doing this frees the development branch up so work can begin on the next release.  At this point the master branch should be 'back merged' into the release branch to resolve any merge conflicts that may have arisen from hot fixes applied to master.

While testing the release bug fixes may need to be applied.  These should be done on the release branch (a bug branch can be created here if the bug fix is complicated so as not to delay testing because of 'work in progress'.  Once the testing is complete the release branch is merged into master and the release pushed to production.

The final step in this cycle is to merge master back into development.  This insures that development has all of the bug fixes created during the release testing cycle as well as all of the hot fixes from master.

example1.title: Release process
example1.label: Merge the approved bug fix into master, push to production and tag the commit

example1.title: Back merge
example1.label: Before testing is completed a 'back merge' from the master branch to the bug branch must be done.  This is done to resolve any merge conflicts and to allow testing of an accurate representation that will be pushed to production.

example1.title: Parallel Bug Fix
example1.label: A second bug fix needs to be worked on in parallel.  This is done on a parallel branch.

example1.title: Merge into Master
example1.label: When the hot fix is ready this branch is merged back into master, deployed to Production and tagged.

example1.title: Merge into Master
example1.label: Any additional work is done against the merged code.  this includes addressing any conflicts between the parallel bug fixes.

example1.title: Merge feature into Development
example1.label: To support integration testing the feature branch is merged into the target release branch.  Typically, with this approach, the release branch will be deployed to a test server

example1.title: Merge development into feature branch
example1.label: To support additional testing the development branch with feature 1 is merged into the feature 2 branch.

example1.title: Merge feature branch to development
example1.label: With the decision made to include feature 2 in the next release the feature 2 branch is merged into development.

example1.title: Create the Release branch
example1.label: The release process is begun by creating a Release branch. All subsequent changes in preparation for the release will be done on this branch. The master branch is merged in to insure that

example1.title: Work on the Release branch
example1.label: The release process is begun by creating a Release branch. All subsequent changes in preparation for the release will be done on this branch. The master branch is merged in to insure that

example1.title: Release to production
example1.label: Once the release is ready merge it into the master branch, push to production and tag the commit

example1.title: Merge master back into development
example1.label: To keep the development branch up to date we merge master back into development

example1.title: Feature development continues
example1.label: To keep the development branch up to date we merge master back into development

example2.title: Initial Master Branch
example2.label: This is the starting point for the flow.  The Master branch should always be in synch with Production.

example2.title: Release 2.0 Branch
example2.label: This branch is used to prepare the 2.0 release.  Features intended for that release will be merged and tested here.

example2.title: Product Hot Fixes
example2.label: To address hot fixes to deal with Production problems a bug branch is created off of master.

example2.title: Merge into Development
example2.label: The hot fix should be merged back into the development branch so that testing can proceed with as close a representation of the code as it will look when deployed to Production as possible.  This is ideally done by merging the master branch back into development.

example2.title: A Second Hotfix
example2.label: This is another hotfix, this one being worked in parallel with an addiitonal hotfix.  This one is targeted to be pushed to production first.

example2.title: Feature Branch
example2.label: Feature development can go on in parallel.  Each feature is worked on in its own branch.  When the feature is complete it can be merged into the development branch.  If there are questions about whether to include the feature in the release it should not be merged until those questions are resolved.

example2.title: Release 3.0.0 Feature
example2.label: A feature intended for Release 3.0.0 is branched off of that release branch.

example2.title: Another Release Branch
example2.label: A second, parallel release branch is created.  This is targetted to be released on a different schedule from Release 2.0.0.

While testing the release bug fixes may need to be applied.  These should be done on the release branch (a bug branch can be created here if the bug fix is complicated so as not to delay testing because of 'work in progress'.  Once the testing is complete the release branch is merged into master and the release pushed to production.

The final step in this cycle is to merge master back into development.  This insures that development has all of the bug fixes created during the release testing cycle as well as all of the hot fixes from master.

example2.title: Release process
example2.label: Merge the approved bug fix into master, push to production and tag the commit

example2.title: Back merge
example2.label: Before testing is completed a 'back merge' from the master branch to the bug branch must be done.  This is done to resolve any merge conflicts and to allow testing of an accurate representation that will be pushed to production.

example2.title: Parallel Bug Fix
example2.label: A second bug fix needs to be worked on in parallel.  This is done on a parallel branch.

example2.title: Merge into Master
example2.label: When the hot fix is ready this branch is merged back into master, deployed to Production and tagged.

example2.title: Merge into Master
example2.label: Any additional work is done against the merged code.  this includes addressing any conflicts between the parallel bug fixes.

example2.title: Merge feature into Release Branch
example2.label: To support integration testing the feature branch is merged into the target release branch.  Typically this release branch will be deployed to a test server

example2.title: Merge Release 2.0.0  into the Feature 2 branch
example2.label: To support additional testing and resolve conflicts the target release branch is merged into the feature 2 branch.

example2.title: Merge feature branch to development
example2.label: With the decision made to include feature 2 in the next release the feature 2 branch is merged into development.

example2.title: Create the Release branch
example2.label: The release process is begun by creating a Release branch. All subsequent changes in preparation for the release will be done on this branch. The master branch is merged in to insure that

example2.title: Work on the Release branch
example2.label: The release process is begun by creating a Release branch. All subsequent changes in preparation for the release will be done on this branch. The master branch is merged in to insure that

example2.title: Release to production
example2.label: Once the release is ready merge it into the master branch, push to production and tag the commit

example2.title: Merge master back into development
example2.label: To keep the development branch up to date we merge master back into development

example2.title: Feature development continues
example2.label: To keep the development branch up to date we merge master back into development

example2.title: Another Feature Intended for Release 2.0.0
example2.label: Feature development continues in parallel.  Each feature is worked on in its own branch.  When the feature is complete it can be merged into the development branch.  If there are questions about whether to include the feature in the release it should not be merged until those questions are resolved.
